required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Bivalirudin With Prolonged Full Dose Infusion Versus Heparin Alone During Emergency PCI
clinical_study.official_title: Bivalirudin With Prolonged Full Dose Infusion Versus Heparin Alone During: a Multicenter, Randomized, Open-label Trial

brief_summary.textblock: This study is aimed to investigate if the bivaliruding with prolonged full dose infusion after PCI is superior to heparin alone in reducing 30-day mortality or major bleeding for patients with STEMI treated with emergency PCI. A total of 6000 STEMI patients will be enrolled and randomly assigned to receive bivalirudin or heparin during emergency PCI in a 1:1 ratio. This study will provide key evidence for peri-operative anticoagulant therapy decisions in STEMI patients.

primary_outcome.measure: Composite of all-cause death or BARC type 3~5 bleeding

secondary_outcome.measure: Major adverse cardiac and cerebral events (MACE)
secondary_outcome.description: MACE is defined as a composite of all cause death, recurrent myocardial infarction, stroke or ischemic driven target vessel revascuarlization
NACE is defined as a composite of MACE or BARC type 3-5 bleeding

secondary_outcome.measure: Composite of all-cause death or BARC type 2-5 bleeding

secondary_outcome.description: Definite or probable stent thrombosis according to Academic Research Consortium
defined as platelet counts less than 150*10^9/L after treatment

arm_group.description: Bivalirudin with prolonged full dose infusion during primary PCI

intervention.description: Bivaliruding 0.75 mg/kg intravenous bolus loading dose, and immediately followed by intravenous infusion of 1.75 mg/kg/h until 2-4 hours after PCI. It is recommended that ACT be monitored 5 minutes after the first administration, and if ACT is <225 s (Hemotec method), intravenous injection of 0.35 mg/kg of bivalirudin should be administered, and the ACT re-checked to ensure it is >225 seconds.

Heparin 70 U/kg is started before coronary angiography. ACT is monitored 5 min after the first administration, and if the ACT <225 s (Hemotec method), an intravenous injection of 1000 U of heparin is administered, and the ACT re-checked to ensure it is >225 seconds.

facility.name: General Hospital of Northern Theater Command
